div.head: TRAFTIC IN HONOURS
div.p: It is worth noting at a moment when there is some talk about the necessity of only granting decorations and grades in Egypt for merit, that King Edward is starting a similar movement in England. "The information which we have had placed at our disposal," says 'The Throne" of the24thalto.,"enables us to state with authority that His Majesty views with extreme disfavour the flagrant manner in which titles have been exploited for party purposes in recent years, and will discountenance most strongly any promotions in the future which are based upon mere liberal contributions to the party funds Titles which ought to be conferred only upon men of high distinction in the realm of intellectual activity have been knocked down to the highest bidder, and these facts have not been disclosed when the name of the prospective peer has been placed before His Majesty for approval. Sir William Jones, in his famous ode in imitation of Alcseus, has given us a magnificent ideal of the State. He reminded us, in words of singular force and beauty, that it does not consist of 'starr'd and spangled courts, where low-bred baseness wafts perfume to pride,' but of high-minded men, 'men who their duties know, but know their rights, snd, knowing, dare maintain.' If England as a nation is to realise that ideal, the honours which she has to confer upon her distinguished sons must not be bought and sold in the political market-place, but should be preserved as a priceless reward for those whose lofty character and intellectual equipment fit them to become the forerunners of a race of statesmen."

div.head: P. AND O. REPORT
div.p: This great company manages to pay 13 per cent. on its Deferred stock with wonderful regularity, and it is fortunate not only in having different sources of revenue, to that where one may fail another makes good the deficiency, but also in having a thoroughly business-like board of directors. It will come as no surprise to stockholders that the freight returns for the year ended September 30 do not compare favourably with those of the previous year, though the apparent deficiency is only £67,475 on a total receipt of £1,521,309, and of this £31,600 is set down to less Government work and lower rates, but the deficiency would have been greater had it not been for the earnings of certain extra voyages. Outward Indian trade was demoralised by a conflict between the English and German lines engaged in the Antwerp branch of this trade, while homeward freights from Indian ports were considerably below the normal point, and cargo was often exceptionally scarce. In Australia freights also suffered in consequence of a fall of nearly 50 per cent in the carrying rates for refrigerated produce, and the cargo fleet engaged in the local trade between India, China, and Japan was not so fully employed as in the previous year. The passenger season, however, was a good one, the total traffic of £1,087,407 being an improvement of £102,719 on last year, but the expense of working the new vessels engaged in this service, which are much larger than the ships replaced, and the further disbursements arising from the extra voyages, materially swelled the expenditure, which, apart from the sinking fund, shows an excess in the cost of navigating the fleet of upwards of £100,000, a considerable proportion of which is attributable to the acceleration of the mail service. The net result of the year's operations is really, very satisfactory, for after setting aside for depreciation £461,097 to sinking fund,the board is enabled to recommend une dividend and bonus as last year.

div.head: International Judicial Commission.
div.p: The International Judicial Commission will meet after the 'Xmas holidays at the Ministry of the Interior, under the presidency of Boutros Pasha Ghali Minister for Foreign Affairs.

div.head: Cairo Scientific Society.
div.p: A meeting of the society will take place at the School of Medicine on Thursday, 13th inst., at 4 30 p.m. The following papers will be read: "River Characteristics as illustrated by the Nile," by Dr. Home; "Fluctuations in the height of the subsoil water in relation to the "Nile Flood," by Mr. A. Lucas.

div.head: "The Globe Trotter"
div.p: Mr. David Garrick Longworth's organ "The Globe Trotter" has appeared in a considerably enlarged form. From the general appearance of the paper and the large number of advertisements which it contains the "Globe Trotter" is progressing fast, and Mr. Longworth's many friends in Egypt will be pleased to hear of his success.

div.head: "The Sphinx."
div.p: Our bright little winter contemporary, the "Sphinx," has made its debut for the season, while entering on its fourteenth year. Last week's issue (the second this season) is if anything an improvement on the first, and both are full of interest to the resident and tourist alike. The journal has the same features as last year—society gossip in Cairo and London, chit-chat interesting personalis, visitors' lists, "Fashions of the Moment,'' "Finance and Matters Financial," a short story by a well-known author, humorous tit-bits, and well-selected articles, besides a number of illustrations, etc. The addition of a new printing department equipped with the most modern machinery and the latest type has enabled the publishers to bring out a handsome publication, which does credit to all concerned.

div.head: British Club.
div.p: The smoking concert given at the British Club on Saturday was a great success in every way, and it is to be hoped will prove to be only the first of a series of similar entertainments. Mr. Heaton opened with a pianoforte solo, and ably served as so accompanist throughout. Mr. Parvis was in good form in the two solos he gave, especially in the favorite "Veteran's Song." He also joined Mr. Sarjeant in a fine rendering of a very telling duet, "Watchman, what of the Night!" composed by Mr. Sarjeant's brother. Mr. De Rougemont delighted every one with his whistling, which beautifully true, and also sang a couple of songs. Mr. Pearce Hill, always a favourite, brought his dolls and managed to check their hilarity though not that of the audience. Mr. Dodwell is a master hand at entertaining, and kept all in roars of laughter throughout his sketches and songs. M.D'Ambra gave four selections on the violin with charming effect and exquisite touch. The chair was taken at first by Sir Massie Blomfield, but owing to the serious illness of Lady Blomfield he had to leave at the interval, and Mr. Gould presided for the rest of the evening. Votes of thanks were pasted to the chairman, and to Mr. Sarjeant for arranging the concert. At the close the prizes won in the billiard handicap were presented by Mr. Gould to the winners, Messrs. Legge, Wood and Sampson.

div.head: Spartall & Co 's Carpets.
div.p: We would call the attention of our readers to an advertisement appearing in to-day's issue of Messrs. J. A. Spartali & Co.'s Oriental carpets. This well known firm, whose head office is at Smyrna, are the largest dealers of hand made Turkish and Persian carpets In the world, and have bean established since 1842. They are manufacturers of all their own goods, having workshops and agencies in all carpet-producing localities of Asia Minor and Persia and employing no less than 10.000 looms and 40,000 weavers; consequently, there being no intermediate profits, the firm is able to offer its goods at prices 25 % to 50 % lower than at the retail shops in Cairo and Alexandria and varying from 13 francs to 150 francs the square metre. Besides a grand selection of modern Oriental carpets of any size and colour Messrs. Sparta'i are prepared to show a choice collection of fine antique rugs and silk rugs of the very finest quality and at moderate prices. They are likewise prepared to execute orders for clients for carpets of any size and colour desired. We would mention that their goods are most suitable for Christmas and New Year's presents to relatives and friends in Europe and America. The firm warm'y invite residents and travelllers to favour their branches in Egypt with a call to inspect the stock just arrived from Smyrns and new being exhibited, with the assurance that visitors will not be importuned to purchase goods they may not require.

Captain Hollefen, commandant of the Ger-man training ship Storch, who was granted audience by the Khedive at Abdeen Palace on Friday, returned to Alexandria on Saturday, from Cairo. The Stosch sails on Saturday next.

div.head: The Rev P.
div.p: B. N. Neman-Lee, C P., is expected to arrive by the troopship Braemar Castle on Thursday next, and will forthwith resume his duties as Chaplain to the Forces in Alexandria, which since his departure in July last have been undertaken by the clergy of 8t. Mark's Church. Canon Ward ceased to be Acting Chaplain to the Forces on December 1.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: On their visit to Egypt this month the Earl and Countess of Halsbury will be accompanied by Mr. and Lady Evelyn Giffard.

div.head:
SERIOUS TRAIN COLLISION.
TWENTY-ONE PASSENGERS INJURED.
div.p: The following telegram was received by us on Saturday evening The Railway Administration regrets to report a serious collision which occurred at Mit Assas this morning and in which one Syrian gentleman received serious injuries and three Europeans and two ladies were slightly injured. All were able to continue their journeys,with the exception of the Syrian gentleman, who was taken to hospital. Fifteen Egyptians received slight injuries, but were able to continue their journeys. The collision occurred during a thick fog. An official erquiry is being made as to the exact cause. Traffic was entirely blocked for some hours, but by this afternoon normal working was again restored. Mit Assas is on the Tautsh to Mansourah line.

div.head:
BURGLARY IN CAIRO
MR. GRAHAM'S HOUSE ENTERED.
div.p: At 4 o'clock yesterday morning the house of Mr. Graham, Deputy Director General of the Public Health Department, at Ghezireh, was broken into by burglars and a considerable amount of old silver plate removed. The police have the affair in hand and are making in-vestigations which it is hoped, will lead to the discovery of the criminals.

Burglary on an extensive scale has hitherto been of rare occurrence in Egypt, but now that the large increase of the suburbs at Cairo and Alexandria offers considerable opportunities to individual or to gangs of thieves it behoves householders to be on their guard.

div.head: AT HOME" ON THE NILE.
div.p: The Hamburg and Anglo-American Nile Company gave a very pleasant "At Home" on board their dahabeah Nubia yesterday afternoon. This fine boat was moored to the land-ing-stage close to Kaar-el-Nil, and was in gala attire, palms and flowers being in profusion and every comfort provided for the guests. Asump-tuous tea was provided in the dainty saloon, which was set out with little tables, while less innocent drinks were served from the smoking-room on the upper desk. The Nubia is one of the finest of this company's steamers, and her accommodation offers every comfort. The roomy cabins have large and airy windows ; and every window is fitted with mosquito blinds, and the cabins all contain ample shelves and chests of drawers and Other conveniences not often met with on board any boat. The upper deck is glazed in at the bows so that no untoward breeze may interfere with the comfort of the passengers ; and everything has been done to ensure the arrangements being as perfect as possible. A continuous stream of people took advantage of the company's invitation to inspect the vessel; and though some of the guests came expecting an afternoon cruise on the river there were few who were not satisfied with the entertainment offered them.

div.head: Y. W. C. A.
div.p: The accommodation at Connaught House proving too limited, the annual sale of work given by the Y. W. C. A. will be held, with the kind permission of George Nuogovich Bey and Mr. Braun, at the Hotel Continental on December 18. The Countess of Cromer has kindly consented to open the proceedings at 3.30, being supported by the Very Rev. Dean Butcher, D.D., in the Chair, and the vote of thanks being proposed by/Major-General Bollock, C.B. By kind permission of Colonel E. A. Herbert, M.V.O., the band of the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons will play daring the afternoon. The sale of work will continue throughout the same evening, the Hon. L. M. lddings American Consul General presiding over the opening ceremony at 8.30 The music during the evening will ba provided by vocalists and a Toy Symphony, four violins and a cello being requisitioned in addition to the usual instruments. The following is a list of the patronesses and of the stalls over which they will preside : England (Children's garments).—Mmes. Alban, Bullock, Butcher, Boyd-Carpenter, Cook-sor, Hogg. Royle, and Vera Alston. Scotland (Woollen goods)—Lady Rogers, Lady Blanche Smith, Lady Willcocks, Mmes Graham, Milton, and Mackenzie. Ireland (Linen goods). — Mmes Johnson Pasha, P. H. Rowlett. and Trevithick. America (Cakes and sweets).—Mmes Id-dings, Crookshank, Foot, Stout, and Tuck. Continent.—Lady Victoria Machell, Miss Farnell. Any contributions of needlework, cakes, sweets, flowers, etc, will be very gratefully received at Connaught House ; and we trust that our readers will take this opportunity of showing their sympathy and appreciation of this most deserving association.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S Sailor Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 8th inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on the I2th.
The Ellerman liner City of Khios arrived in Liverpool on Saturday morning.
The S.S. Bulgarian (Wesscott Line) left Malta on the 8th inst., and is due here on Wednesday next with general cargo from London and Malta.

div.head:
SUEZ CANAL BLOCKED.
CLAN LINER ASHORE.
div.p: (From our CORRESPONDENT.)

Suez Monday. The S.S Clan Macdonald is ashore in the Canal at kil. 146 station, and is blocking the passage of the Indian mailboat Mooltan, which has already been delayed 15 hours. Suez Later. The Clan Macdonald has been refloated, but cannot move owing to a chain in her propeller.

div.head:
THE S.S. NEGHILLEH.
RETURNS TO SUEZ UNDAMAGED.
div.p: Suez, Saturday. The S.S. Calioubieh returned to Suez this forenoon. from Gemsab, and reports having successfully pulled the S.S. Neghilleb off the reefs. The vessel is apparently undamaged, and will very likely return to Suez tomorrow. Suez, Sunday. The Khedivial steamer Neghilleb, which was ashore at Gemsah, returned to Suez at 7.80 this morning and has been drydocked.

div.head: REAL ESTATE AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writer Five months ago La Societe d'Entreprises Immobilieres et de Travanx,. Cairo, made arrangements to take over 10% (80,000 pips) of the land owned by La Societe Civile des Terrains Cleopatre of Alexandria. This land has a superficial area of about .300.000 pies, and is situated at Ibrahimieh (Alexandria) on the sea front. They bought the land in Jane last from Messrs. Stagni and Zervudachi for P.T. 101 per pic. The Municipality has now decided to extend the Alexandria promenade quay as far as Sidi Gaber, which work will necessitate catting through the whole length of the Cleopatre possessions. The necessary funds for carrying out this work have already been voted by the Municipality. One can see at a glance that the value of this property has already been considerably enhanced, and it is estimated that there will be no difficulty in obtaining P.T. 200 to P.T. 230 per pic for this land. At the present moment there are firm offers on hand lor certain parcels at P.T. l60 per pic. which represents a net profit of P.T. 69 per pic on purchase price. If the Societe d'Entreprises Immobilidres et de Travanx ware to realize to day their portion of the property, the sale would net them a clear £18 000, and this on an expendi-ture of £7,500 made last June. As no doubt the property will be disposed of at a more advantageous figure, a considerably larger profit will result therefrom.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: "FRANCILLON."

"Autres temps, autres mceurs"; old de Riverolles tale of the Middle Ages seems now hardly more antiquated than Dumas 20 year-old play itself. By so much have we progressed or—become blaze. And, paradoxically, "plus ca change plus c'est la meme chose; there is the usual triangle, this time an isosceles one, its sides composed of suspicions of husband and wife married "a outrance" on a very weak basis of infidelity, and the denonement no less laborious than the Pons Asinorum. We hardly care to think how a Dumas of to-day would fare with a piece whose meagre plot and interminable dialogues are equalled only by its want of plausibility and action. The constant repetition of the main theme by nearly every character soon becomes tedious. There is hero and there a redeeming epigram, but on the whole the play offers little opportunity, nor did we think that, when produced on Saturday, that little was pushed to its uttermost possibility. Even Mile Marthe Brandes in the title idle did not mark her debut in Alexandria with anything beyond an averagely good performance. For this, no doubt a severe cold, from which she was suffering, was in a measure responsible. And then the part is wordy and refitted and hence deprives its interpreter of a good deal of the effect to be gained by appeals to the imagination. It may well be that a stage idea of the 'femme du monde' is to keep the emotions genteelly in check; still there was surely room for rather more colour and "abandon'' in "Francillon" than Mile Brandis imparted. Setting aside M Arnaud, the present troupe is certainly better than Mme Hading's com-pany, in that they shew confidence and pull well together. On Saturday no one player stood out from amongst the others, so it would be invidious to draw distinctions. This evening, "L'Espionne" will be give

div.head: MAPLE &Co., Ltd.

div.head:
KISWET EL MAHMAL.
CEREMONY AT THE CITADEL
div.p: Topped by the mosque and ifs minarets, the Citadel stands clear against the sky: the blood , red standard scarce flatters in the morning breeze, and the ramparts are fringed will an evergrowing line of figures, clad in every abade of ooloar but mostly capped with crimson tarboosh. The crowd in the place below grows denser every moment as the morning mists roll away and carriage after carriage flits its way into the enclosure. For civilized and Europeanized as is our Cairo, this great festival, centred round the departure of the Holy Carpet for Mecca, is still one of the great events of the calendar and is eagerly awaited by both Mohamedan and Christian. The night before its departure the heavily embroidered panels and the sacred Mahmal were 'en evidence'. under cover, and great was the crowd that circled round it and joined the audience in the adjoining tent where Dervishes chanted their endless verses, and devotees persisted in their devotions till the onlookers grew weary of the drowsy monotony and strange barbaric musical intervals. But the morning ceremony held under the blue canopy of heaven and with accompaniment of military display appeals more to the ordinary observer and bolds attention from first to last. The native crowd, so full of colour and movement, the mounted police reducing chaos into semblance ,of order, the stretch of sand-covered road winding round the Citadel and up the slope beyond, the wide parade ground lined with rigid troops, and the constant stream of carriages and people, keep eyes and senses always on the alert. High officials, gorgeous in their gold-laced uniforms, with brightly coloured orders and glittering decorations, whirl by; and also many native notabilities in wonderful eastern garb and flowing garments of various hues with embroideries of gold about their necks and encircling their turbans. Some drive in state behind proudly stepping horses; others arrive in humble arabeshs, the effect made grotesque at times by the figure of a ragged urchin taking a free ride behind. Closed broughams flash by containing visions of veiled ladies of state, and the latest arrivals from England in the latest thing in motor cars presses largely to the fore. But all are ready in their places, and all the soldiers spick and span and well to attention before the clatter of the Lancer escort proclaims the arrival of H.H. the Khedive and his entourage in the highly swung barouche with syces and outriders. The strains of the National Anthem, Royal salutes, and shouts from the male population greet his arrival, while the curious twittering cries from the native women add an element most curious and unusual to the sound. In the meanwhile the Kiewet el-Mahmal has been borne into the centre of the ground : the ' gorgeous tent-like creation has been already lifted into position upon the honoured camel, all richly caparisoned and almost covered with its saddle cloth and headpiece of gold and crimson. The Mahmal itself is so overladen with heavy gold and silver bullion that scarce any of its crimson ground is visible. High silver ornaments are at its angles, its silver apex gleams from under a falling fringe of black. Swaying to the movement of the camel it scintillates and blazons in the sunshine and moves slowly across the ground past the Khedive, and starts the first stage of its long and weary journey followed by the plaintive music of flats and native drum. Stretched on long domed frames of wood, and looking for all the world like enormous ambulance litters, follow the various portions of the sacred carpet. They are carried on the stalwart shoulders of duffel clad gaffirs; and while some are covered, all with black, others display their glittering , inscriptions from the Koran upon a ground of black or green. After them stream the various regiments : first the Lancers with their band playing, somewhat inappropriately,very English music, then the guns of the field battery and the mule battery, and after them detachments of the Egyptian line. After the long stream has passed away out of sight and the final salute is over, the Khe-dive drives off in his state carriage across the ground, and the great function is over. Within half an hour the crowd has drifted back to its highways and byeways, and the Citadel is once more left to keep solitary watch and ward over the town at its feet.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA FIRE BRIGADE.
div.p: SATURDAY'S DISPLAY.

As a demonstration of technical ingenuity, combined with simplicity of manoeuvre, the display of the Alexandria Fire Brigade, held on Saturday afternoon, at Moharem Bey, under the direction of Miralai Hockinson, deserved the highest praise. But more than this. The feature that stood forth most conspicuously, at that exhibition,was neither the excellency of the equipment, nor the superior make of the machinery ; it was rather, if the writer's allegory may be permitted, (he high standard of efficiency of the "human machine"— effi cient in every detail of the manifold duties involved in the fireman's risky work. The raw, untutored, undisciplined Arab or Fellah has been taken in hand, and by the devotion of British and European instructors, formed into a handy, able-bodied man. The. engine may be perfect, hot it is after all the man behind it that tells. The brigade whom Superintendent Waller marshalled on Saturday before his Excellency the Governor and a goodly gathering of local portabilities—official and civilian- were as fine a body of men as one could wish to see ; splendid physique, and for all their swarthy faces, very imposing in their dazzling brass helme's. There were a promptitude to obey and enthusiasm in action which augur well, and it was also not a little gratifying to note the keen delight shown by the native population, a huge concourse of whom covered the steep slope of Kom el Dik; they were especially jubilant over the operations for rescuing one of their own kith and kin,who his bare and puny legs swinging in the wind, was let down from the top storey window. The display commenced with inspection parade of brigade and equipment, consisting of three fire engines, one automobile; a manual engine ; pompier ladder; long ladder; and hose reel. To avoid tediousness, we will con-fine ourselves to a generalisation of the several , items of the programme. The drilling was , perfect, and the record of time in which the work was carried out, remarkable. For instance the manual engine was got in'o action, pump pipe, and all, by one man within 1.41 minutes. The pompier ladder, whose uses were next demonstrated, is, we believe, a French invention ; the books at the end of the short ladders employed in climbing from storey to storey reminded one of the fore feet of that interesting invertebrate, the Walking Stick insect Reaching the top of one ladder, the fireman secured himself by a catch to the sill, while he fixed on the ladder he carried to the upper floor; the rungs were attached to a centre—piece like fish- bones to the spine, and the saw—like appearance made one shudder. The rope used in the escape is of coreless multiple strand called "Simonis," of London make, very light and thin, but of immense strength. We had also a practical demonstration of the water curtain, which so ingeniously protects the fireman by a circular spray at right angles to the jet The chemical cylinder, containing carbonic acid gas, that rapidly extinguished a fierce fire, and the smoke helmet, were also interesting. The long ladder is eighty feet in length. At full span, it looks top heavy, but except for an initial list, the carriage on which it stands scarcely creaked, no matter what way the ladder was turned. It is of German manu- factors, built by Honig of Cologne, and not the latest thing in ladders, for by the newest invention the fireman is winched up by a motor engine. But for Alexandria, which at present is free of sky scraping architecture, the German apparatus will suffice. The motor fire engine was, as with the others, constructed by the well known firm of Merryweather of London ; it was converted to automobility recently by an expert sent from London, Under 120 pounds pressure, or 12 H P., it can run 16| miles an bour. A word for the horses of the other engines. They are nearly all South of England breed ; they are thoroughly trained and powerful drays, which, for all the sandy roil, drew op instantaneously, even at full gallop. The "house on fire" scene was the grande finale, most realistic with just a suspicion of smoke —the spectators would have bean delighted with a good old blaze but proximity to the station buildings forbade ; or perhaps the house was too wet After the gallop past the parade reformed, and his Excellency the Governor congratulated Superintendent Waller and his men on their admirable performance.

div.head: UNITED-EGYPTIAN LANDS. LTD.
div.p: The public appear to be undersome misapprehension as to the length of time daring which their money will be locked up after having sent in their applications for shares for the United Egyptian Lands, Limited. The allotment will take place in Egypt so far as one third of the capital is concerned. The allotment letters and cheques will be sent out to applicants certainly not later than the end of the present week. The United Egyptian Lands, Limited, has secured an option, in addition to the 55,000 metres referred to in the prospectus, on land on Rodah Island. This brings up the total to over 220 000 square metres and works out at under £2.l0s. per metre, including all charges. The land is excellently situated with a frontage on the Nile. The Garden City plots are fetching from £5 to £14 per metre and the land immediately opposite at Gbizeh from £4 to £6, so the option obtained by the United lands must be considered exceptionally favourable.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE
"FAUST
div.p: "Feast" opened well enough. We had three new people. M Massas Mephistopheles, Mile Baron as Margoerite, and M. M<hy as Valentine. If the whole performance had not tailed off so wretchedly we should have appreciated them. Mile Baron can act; and it is the greatest possible relief to see a Marguerite who has any notion of acting. The "Thole" song was perhaps her best achievement. The tremolo—wh'ch she uses far too much—came in as a "roucoulement"—a real spinning-wheel song. crooned to herself. The Jewel song would hare been even better, but she spoilt it by a "show" high note at the end which dramatised her soliloqoy out of its proper form Her acting was especially good in the church scene with Mephistopheles: many slight touches, her concentration on the mass-book from which her thoughts were so far absent, her painful progress across the stage kneeling— these and much else proved her merit but her voice seems tired, and now and again she uses that tremolo to avoid an awkward semitone or accidental. M. Maas was not bad, but seemed to have bad quite enongh of the play long before the end. M. Mezy has little enough to do, but his voice is good, with plenty of strength and far more 'colour' than those of the others. M. Fontaine, I was told, had been suffering from dengue. He must have had it from the beginning of the season than ; he showed the same tendency to force his notes, especially in the lower register, as he did in 'Manon' and "Romeo and Juliette." It is a pity, as his higher, more emotional notes are the "real thing." But why does he make up so badly! He always appears grotesque with that absurd beard and moustache arrangement In "Manon," after the first two acts he was well made up, and naturally; and it made all the difference in the world. Siebel (Mile Karl) and Marthe (Mile Burizy) were fair. The chorus end orchestra were very bad : the former were stiff, and at best noisy, and in the soldiers' chorus they looked like a lot of gaffiers on parade. The latter, as I have already said, seems to be always asleep and flat. The conductor has no sort of entrain. He gets through it all anyhow and never makes a point of any sort. No wonder the operas go badly! The famous Escalais appears at length in 'William Tell tomorrow (Saturday) night; so we shall see the company in its more serious aspect. Let us hope for a vivid and striking contrast to the first few efforts. It is, I think, no use people talking (as I have heard and read lately) about the small Opera House, the difficulties, etc, etc. I can't see any sort of excuse for the shortcomings. We need not expect Caruso and Melba, but surely the receipts end whatever help the company get should ensure at least a really good second-class troupe. Really, when one is driven to indulgence in comparison with the Abbas and ci-devantt Verdi Theatres, with any stage where any singing can be heard, one resents hearing the Opera Home spoken of as the chief Khedivial Theatre, etc.. etc. No one likes having dost thrown in his eyes!
'GUILLAUME TELL'

''Guillaume Tell" was a startling and wel-come change. M Escalais, Mezy. Mass, and Mile Devilloy are all four, of a different class to any we have yet heard : they are grand opera, and very good grand opera at that. M. Escalais has a great resonant voice : his high notes are those of a clarion shaking and echoing through the house; his diction and declamation are those of a great singer. Of course his acting and, in a sense, some of his singing are entirely stereotyped and traditional: be is, except for those high notes, a type and not an individual He sang rather flat now and again in the lower and middle registers and was inclined to skirt round the note ; and in those same registers was a suspicion of wear and tear and effort His finest singing was in the duet with Mathilde. the "J'expire" and the trio, and the two songs in the last act, "Mes ami." and ''Asile muet" M. Mass was more at home than as Mephistopheres, and the depth and "roundness" of his voice had foull scope. M. Mezy though, was the triumph of the evening. His voice, a great baritone, had every shade of strength and colour and drama : and his acting was equally fine and not nearly so strewed as that of the rest. Mile Deviloy had not half enough to do, from our point of view. She is, I really think, the most perfect of the sopranos. She has far more tone than Mile Baron, and though she has hardly the training of Mile Charpentier, her voice is infinitely sweeter: never a disagreeable or harsh note, or a shadow of fatigue or thinness, and her notes were sweetness itself. Those phases of the opera I have mentioned, -and I add Mezy's singing and acting before "Gessler"—were as near perfection as could be. As for the rest, the orchestra did the overtore well, and kept to a fairly good standard most of the time ; but in the trio— Walther, Arnold and Guillaume Tell—it was again shaky and inaccurate. The players do not respond enough. Mile Karl acted well all through, but her singing lacks certainty : she never seems sure of herself or her voice. M. Durand looked like Henry VIII. in a most tyrannical "get-up," and sang well enough. The others one may as well pass over. The chorus must have a special condemnation. The breakdown in the 3rd act, the general tuneless-ness and carelessness seem to show an entire lack of drilling or training. I admit most of them seemed to know it, and to be sorry for what was probably not their fault; but one or two of the worst offenders (I think they were in last year's chorus) seemed hopelessly satisfied with themselves and stared and sang into vacancy with the most deplorable aplomb. Of ballets, I am no judge : opinions seemed to differ; but certainly I am thankful in that the vision of fleshly poetry of motion caused one worthy at least behind me to stop making horrible noises with programme, feet, throat, and other accessories that were not meant by the Creator as annoyances to one's fellow-creatures! At one moment I would have given much for a powerful and wide-spreading narcotic for use in the stalls.

The special correspondent of the "Times" at San Francisco deplores the whole agitation against the Japanese as causeless, artificial, and wicked, and solely due to the agitation of the Labourites. The Japanese are being humiliated in a thousand ways. They are patient, hot assaults on their part are becoming rather frequent. The situation appears to be dangerous. (Reuter)

div.head:
RUSSIA AND JAPAN.
EDUCATION BILL.
JAPANESE UNCONCILIATORY.

div.p: The RUsso-Japanese negotiations with regard
to a commercial and fishing convention are progressing very slowly. The Russians com-plain that the Japanese are unconciliatory and make impossible proposals. (Reuter)
Admiral Touchard's squadron has arrived. Two Spanish cruisers from Cadiz have also arrived (Feuter)
The French squadron has arrived. (Havas)
The "Lokalanzeiger" comments on the visit of Mr. Doumer to Prince vou Bulow. It says that the visit proves the desires of France to live on good terms with Germany.
The police seised a large collection of arms
and ammunition at the Rakoff blast furnaces. 87 revolutionaries were arrested. (Havas)

div.head:
THE PRINCESS ROYAL.
AGAIN UNDERGOES OPERATION.

div.p: The Princess Royal has again undergone an operation. Her Royal Highness is progressing satisfactorily. (Reuter)

div.head:
FIRE AT CORNELL UNIVERSITY
SEVEN LIVES LOST.

div.p: A fire has occurred at Cornell University in
which four stadents and three firemen lost their lives. (Reuter)
As the Indian outward mail was passing the
station of Chateaoneuf, near Montelimar, a piece of projecting iron struck one of the carriages and injured several persons, one of whom was mortally injured. (Reuter)
The Government proposes to establish branches of the National Rank of China at Chi fu Tsing-tae, Oalgan, Urga, and Kiath-ta, with a view of promoting foreign trade. ( Feuter)
A Servian band has assailed and occupied the Bulgarian convent of Tresbaret. The monks were killed. (Havas)
The Shah is slightly better, but very weak.
(Reuter)
Speaking at Dublin, Mr. Austin Chamberlain
said that his father was making continued progress and was confident of hie return to public Iife next year. (Reuter)
Football. Rugby. The match between the South Africans and England was drawn. A try was scored on each side. (Reuter)

The correspondence relating to the Newfoundland modas vivendi has bean published. It reveals the fact that a regular polemic had developed between the Imperial and Newfoundland Government, the latter rotesting against interference with its internal affairs, and Lord Elgin insisting on the right of the Imperial Government to intervene on questions touching the relations between the Empire and foreign States. (Reuter)
At a prolonged Cabinet Council held yesterday evening, the Peers' Amendments to the Education Bill were discussed. (Feuter)

House of Commons.—A prolonged discussion took place on the Bill for the Provision of Meals for School Children. The House rose at 8.80 in the morning. Many Liberals criticized the principle of the Bill. (Reuter)
M. Brunetiere, of the French Academy, is dead. (Havas)

div.head: The Thankful 3.
div.p: Mother, Daughter, and Neighbour, Rescued from Fainting Flts.
New Blood for an Anaemic.
St. Vitus' Dance Dispelled.
Three Cures by
DR. WILLIAM'S PINK PILLS.

Three people in one Linconlshire village-mother, daughter, and neighbour's child— whose sufferings arose from a single cause, namely, weak and bad blood, have found overtiming new strength and vitality in Dr. William's Pink Pills for Pale People, the one remedy that could fill their veins with the rich red blood of health.

"My mother was for years subject to fainting fits" said Miss Emma E. Booth, when interviewed at Broadholms, Saxilby, Lincolnshire. "She would fall to the floor like a stone under these terrible weakening attacks, and she continued to suffer from this most obstinate farm of acute debility until my father bought Dr. Williams Pink Pills for her. As my mother took the pills she quickly realised they were the one thing needful to bring her back to health, for the fainting fits left her, and as her blood became enriched, so she regained strength until life and work became a pleasure again.

I, myself, have suffered from aneamia," Miss Booth continued, "since I was fourteen. Gradually my health went from bad to worse until a crisis came. Then I lost every atom of energy, becoming quite bloodless and weak. Severe headaches, discomforting pains in the chest, and an irresistible languid feeling made my days unbearable. I had terrifying dreams at night, which caused me to grow dreadfully nervous, and slowly and surely I became thin, pale and careworn. At times I felt as if I would drop down over my work through sheer helplessness ; I had no appetite whatever and was always breathless and subject to palpitations. No medicine did me any good ; in fact, it would have bean a relief to lie down and die.

"Then my mother advised me to lose no time but taka Dr. Williams' Pink Pills; for she said I needed new blood to make me well. So I took the pills and very soon my appetite returned ; I began to gain strength ; my colour came back and I put on flesh. Since taking five boxes of Dr. Williams' Pink Pills I have enjoyed the bast of health, and I eat, sleep, and work well now with no traces at all of the many ills that follow in the train of anaemia.
"When our neighbour's little girl had an

attack of St. Vitus' Dance, twitching and jerking her limbs, with convulsive movements of her features, my mother recommended these pills again, for poor blood causes weak nerves, and in this third case we were delighted to find that Dr. Williams' Pink Pills effected a complete cure."

For both sexes, and for many disorders apparently different in nature, Dr. Williams Pink Pills are equally valuable ; the reason of this great success is due to their wonderful power of reinforcing and enriching the blood. All the diseases that arise from watery or vitiated blood have been cured by these pills, including Anaemia, Indigestion, Eczema, Rheumatism, and Nervous Disorders such as St. Vitus Dance, Sciatics, Neuralgia, Paraly-is ; also the ailments that afflict Women only. Only the genuine pills, those labelled in foil on every box Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People, effect these cures. Of all dealers, or in case of doubt send 2s. 9d for one box, or 13 9d for six boxes to the British Depot 46, Holborn viaduct, London.

div.head: CAIRO BRITISH RIFLE CLUB
div.p: On Friday the Club shot off a match against the 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards at Abbassieh. Owing to changing light and a tricky wind, soaring was not high. The club team, whose scores are given below, won by 36 Points.
W. Fletcher 28 + 29 + 27 = 84
J. Kearney 19 + 31 + 23 — 83
D. Macdonald 23 + 30 + 28 = 81
P. S. Anderson-87 + 27 + 27 = 81

Shooting for the rifle given by the Hon. F. O. Lindley will commence next Friday at Tourah, at 200 and 500 yards. The competition is confined to members who joined the club since January 1, and club rifles most be need. The best two scores out of three shoots will win.

Dlrectors :

Elie Toriel (Director Egyptian Lands and General Trust, Limited). Alexandria. J. Rupert Campbell(Chairman Egyptian Lands and Agency, Ltd.), Cairo. AUGUSTE Rossano (Messrs. Rossano Freres & Co.) Cairo. Alfred Chamass (Director Societe des Automobiles et des Omnibus du Caire), Cairo. Edward Forti (Manager Banque de Sa'onique), Alexandria.
Bankers:
Basque de Salonique, Alexatdria.

Russell, KErr & Wyatt, Cairo, Alexandria, and London.

Secretary & Local Offices :
A. P. Phillips, F.C.I.8.,
Maison Spiro, Sharia Kaar-el Nil, Cairo.
PROSPECTUS.

This Company has been formed for the purposes set out in its Memorandum of Association, to carry on business in Egypt and the Sudan, and more particularly to develop the well-known health resort of Helouan, near Cairo, by the acquisition of Land and Building sites, and by the erection of Buildings thereon, and generally with the object of acquiring interests of divers kids in this rapidly improving district.

Although facilities for the acquisition of properties in Helouan will it is believed be afforded the Directors, yet no existing or proposed contracts to be entered into by the Co. on its inception are in force.

It is unnecessary to point out the paramount position held by Helouan as a health and pleasure resort, as the fame of its curative mineral springs and delightful climatic condi-tians are so well known and appreciated. But what is interesting to know, from a commercial point of view, is that the rapid growth of Helouan has attracted the attention of investors to the opportunities that now offer for the remunerative employment of capital in its development.

Helouan is situate about 16 miles from Cairo, and is connected by the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, the directors of which are so alive to the future of this rising suburb of Cairo, that they have or are about to expend £60,000 in improving this branch of their line. The line to Tourah was recently doubled, thus accelerating the communication and enabling the Company to put on a frequent service of Express Trains, (the journey occupying about 30 minute'). The passenger service has already been equipped with luxurious modem corridor carriages fitted with Electric Light.

Helouan is becoming increasingly popular as a residential, district tor City professional and business men, and a growing demand is apparent-for more improved and commodious habitations than at present exist.

The yearly influx of visitors steadily continues, hotel and other residential establishments are feeling the tax on their resources to adequately meet the requirements of those seeking the health-giving advantages of Helouan's desert air.
The Golf Links, Racecourse, Paddock, Racing Stables, etc., are important attractions, and the surroundings afford the most enjoyable place for horse exercise near Cairo.
The following is given in compliance with the requirements of the Companies Act, 1900.
The provision in the Articles of Association as to the remuneration of the Directors are as follows :—

" As remuneration for his services as a " Director the Chairman shall receive " remuneration at the rate of £300 per ' annum, and the other Directors shall " receive remuneration at the rate of £250 " per annum. In addition to the said fixed " remuneration there shall be divided be " tween the Directors, in such manner as ' they may determine, a sum equal to 10 " per cent. on the profits certified by " auditors of the Company to have teen " made in each year in excess of a sum " sufficient to provide a dividend of six

" per cent upon the amount paid up or ' credited as paid up, on the Ordinary " Shares for the time being, having re-" gard to the provisions as to the division " of profits hereinbefore contained, but " without making any provision for a " reserve fund. "

' The remuneration of a Managing Director " or a Director or Directors, as managers " shall, from time to time, be fixed by the " Directors, and may he by way of Salary " or commission, or participation in profits,
" or by any or all of these modes. "

" If any Director, being willing, shall he " called upon to perform extra service, or " to make any special exertions in going " or residing abroad, or otherwise for any " of 'he purposes of the Company, or act ' as trustee for the Company or its De-" benture holders, and shall do so, the " Company may remunerate such Director " either by a fixed sum or by a percentage " of profits or otherwise as may be deter " mined by the Directors, and such " pemuneration may he either in addition " to or in substitution for his remunera-" tion above provided. "

By a contract dated 17th November, 1906, and made between Andrew Percy Phillips on behalf of the Company and the Egyptian Lands and Agency, Limited, who are in consideration of paying all the costs, charges and expenses of and incident to the preparation, executing, stamping and registration of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company, and the preparation, advertising, printing and the circulating of the prospectus, and all charges and legal expenses up to and including date of allotment, exclusive of stamps on Share Warrants, or ary brokerage in respect of such capital, to receive a sum of seven thousand five hundred pounds from the Company.

The Egyptian Lands and Agency, Limited, has farther undertaken to underwrite, for a commission of five per cent, payable by the Company, eighty five thousand Shares of £1 each. This contract will he adopted by the Company.
Various sub underwriting contracts exist: —
Two Directors, Mr. Elie Toriel and Mr. J. Rupert Campbell are interested in the promotion of the Company to the extent of 500 shares each in the Egyptian Lands and Agency Limited.
The Direotors are interested as underwriters, and each will receive the five per cent, on the number of shares underwritten by him as, follows
Elia Toriel, 5000 shares. J. Rupert Campbell, 2.000 shares. Auguste Rossano, 3,000 shares. Alfred Chamass, 3,000 shares, and Edward Forti 2,000 shares.

Applications for Shares should he made on the accompanying form and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company's Bankers. If no allotment is made, the application money will he returned in full, and where the number of shares alloted is less that that applied for the surplus will be credited in redaction to this amount payable on allotment, and any excess will be returned to the Applicant.
Failure to pay any instalment when due, will render the previous payments liable to be forfeited. .
A copy of the Memorandum of Association, which forms part of this Prospectus, is endorsed hereon. |
The minimum subscription upon which the Director may proceed to Allotment has been fixed by the Articles of Association at £100,000. i

A brokerage of Sixpence per Share will be; paid to Brokers and Bankers on all Shares applied for and allotted to the public on Ap-. plication Forms hearing their stamps. No claims for brokerage will he recognised by the company unless the Application Form is distinctly stamped with the name and address of Brokers whose clients are subscribing.
A Print of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company, and the above-mentioned Contract, can be inspected at the Offices of Maltre Carton de Wiart, Cairo.
Copies of this Prospeotus and Application; Forms can be obtained at the Local Offices of the Company, and from the Company's Bankers.

This Company has been formed for the purposes set out in its Memorandum of Associa-tion; and especially to carry on business in Egypt and the Soudan. The attention of the Board will, as opportunities present themselves, be more particularly- directed to
1. The purchase, development and sub-sequent leasing or re sale of agricultural and building land.
2. The lending of money, on mortgage or otherwise on land or other approved securities.
3. The carrying on of the business of an Investment Company.

The removal of all possibility of friction, due ' to the Anglo-French Agreement, and the con-fidence engendered by the certainty of a pro-traded British administration, has added the element of stability to Egypt which it pre- viously lacked.

That this vital fact is being realised is clearly shown by the remarkable progress now being made in agriculture and commerce, which again is reflected in the ever-increas-ing prosperity of the natives and the steady rise in value of all property. While the rise in land values during the last few years has been remarkable, those who are best acquainted with the conditions of the country end its people are emphatically of the opinion that a further steady increase of prosperity and a corresponding improvement in values is assured.

The increasing wealth of the natives, whose one form of investment is agricultural land, coupled with the fact of their rapid numerical increase and the natural limit imposed upon the cultivation of new land by the amount of water available for irrigation, all tend to increase the capital and rental values of such land as is either actually under cultivation or is approaching that stage; in addition to which, there always remains the fact that, even if the utmost possibilities foreshadowed by Sir William Garstin as to water supply were fulfilled, it is estimated by Mr. Lang Anderson, that at most about another one and a half million acres could be brought into agricultural use in the whole of Egypt, and that, only alter an expenditure of over ten millions sterling, during a period of twenty years. At the end of 1904, roughly five and . a quarter million acres of land were held by about one million owners, of whom nearly seven-eighths were native holders of less than five acres each. With an estimated present population of about eleven millions, which is steadily increasing at the rate of about 8 per

cent per annum, and with a revenue and a foreign trade which have increased over 60 and 100 per cent. respectively during the last 25 years, it would appear that the expression need in Lord Cromer's Report of March last that "the material prosperity of the country rests on a basis of somewhat exceptional solidity" is amply justified.

In view of the facts above stated this Com pany will mainly devote itself to the development of selected agricultural estates with a view to their rental or sale to natives in plots suitable to their requirements. Excellent opportunities frequently occur of lending money on first mortgage at good rates and with an ample margin. With a local Advisory Board composed of business men of high standing and long experience in Egypt good profits may reasonably be expected from this and other forms of investment which require special local knowledge.
Mr. John Hicks Pauli, the well-known Agricultural Expert in Egypt, has joined the Advisory Board, and will act as the Company's technical adviser for a period of three years.

The Company has acquired from The H. and J. Syndicate, Limited, the right to purchase the Kom-EI-Akhdar estate of 4,793 feddans (say 5,000 English sorts), situated about 50 miles south of Alexandria, and connected by a tramway, 1 1/2 miles in length, with The Delta Light Railways system. Mr. R. Laug Anderson has reported to The H. and J. Syndicate, Limited, upon the property, and a copy Of his Report is sent herewith.

It will be noted. that he states that the supply of water appears to be excellent, and the property well supplied with main canals. That the soil varies from a very light sandy loam to a heavy black loam, but is all suitable for cultivation of the usual crops of Lower Egypt That the principal buildings are in excellent condition, and quite sufficient for the property-at present, but more accommodation for tenants will have to be built yearly as the land comes to the letting stage. That the number of working bullocks is sufficient for reclamation purposes, and there is a good supply of moles, houses and donkeys for transport work. The usual crops of cotton, berseem, wheat and barley were doing well. That the property was capable of great development at moderate cost, and if £30,000 were judiciously spent on it during the next five years it could be brought to a capital value of £75 to £80 per feddan. That the work of development is simple and follows well known lines, so that the element of unforeseen contingencies was largely diminished, while the results of develop-ment were sure. That he advises the property is a good investment at £45 per feddan, and confidently recommends the purchase. That if money on development is well spent, the capital value will increase enormously yearly. That the present rental received is L.E. 3,841 600 (=£3,940 sterling), that is £4 per feddan in respect of 980 feddans let, and he states that in his opinion, when fully reclaimed, the whole of the property should let at an even better rent—4,793 feddans at, say, £1 101. per feddan, would give an income of £21,500 per annum.
The H. and- J. Syndicate, Limited, have obtained an option on a valuable property, of about 55,000 metres, at Rhode Island, Cairo, which can be secured by this Company at a satisfactory price.
The Directors have other business in view Which is believed to be of a most profitable nature ; as, however, negotiations are still in progress, it is not possible to give details at present
Full details, &c., can be obtained by intending applicants at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank.
COPY OF Mr. R. LANG ANDERSON'S REPORT.

div.head: 15, Rue de la Gare de Ramleh, Alexandrie, Egypt, 24th May1906.
div.p: Dear Sir,
KOM-EL-AHDAR PROPERTY.
Having visited the Kom-al Ahdar property,
I beg to report as follows: —

SITUATlON.— The property is well situated and easily got at, being about 50 miles southeast Alexandria and only 1 1/2 miles distant from Kom-al-Ahdar Station on the Delta Light Railway, from which point there is a 60 centi-metre tramway to the principal homestead.
Irrigation —The supply of water appeared to be excellent, and the property is well sup-plied with main canals.

Drainage on the greater part of the Estate is good, but the drains are too few in number and not deep enough. The whole property would greatly benefit, in my opinion, by a closer and deeper system of canalisation. About l,000 feddans, more or less, are comparatively low lying and many require to have their drainage pumped during part of the year to reclaim them properly.
Soil varies from a very light sandy losm to a heavy black loam, but is all suitable for cul-tivation of the usual crops of Lower Egypt.

Buildings.—The principal buildings, which are in excellent condition, are quite sufficient for the property, but more accommodation for tenants will have to be built yearly as the land come to the letting stage.
STOCK—The number of working bullocks is sufficient for reclamation purposes, and there is a good supply of mules, horses, and donkeys for the transport work.

Present Condition. - The usual crops of cotton, berseem, wheat, and barley are doing well, end on the high light soil all round the principal dwelling house, orange and lemon trees would grow well. On several parts of the Estate the cotton was looking very well, but on other parts it was doing badly, simply due, in my opinion, to having been planted on land not yet sufficiently reclaimed to grow the crop. Rice was being grown as a reclamation crop, and would be better it the drains were closer and deeper and the land more carefully levelled before the crop was sown.

Future Development. The property is capable of great development at moderate cost. 'If £30,000 is judiciously spent on it during the next three years, it can be brought to a capital value of £75 to £80 per feddan. The work of development is simple and follows well known lines, so that the element of unforeseen contingencies is largely diminished, while the results of development are sure.

Conclusion.—The property is a good invest-ment at £45 a feddan. The revenue for the first year or two will he small, but if the money on development is well spent the capital value will be increasing enormously yearly, and later on the revenue will come in and go on increasing until at least £4 10ss is reached. I can confidently recommend the purchase of this Estate of 4,793 feddans, which, according to Mr. Sursack's figures, has at present a rental

of L.E. 3,841,600. from an area of 980 feddan let, which is slightly over £4 sterling per feddan and I see no reason why the whole of the pro-perty when fully reclaimed, should not do even better, as some of the let land is not, in my opinion, quite ready to give to tenants, and if the proprietor had kept it in his own hands for another year under reclamation crops he could have got a higher rent.
Yours faithfully, (Signed) R. Lang Anderson
C. T. Holland, Esq.,
The H. and J. Syndicate Limited.
VALUATION OF KOM-EL-AHDAR.
Gross Area 4,793 Feddans.
Und Let 980 feds. £64 p. fed £62,720
Cultivated by Proprietor 1185 „ „50 „ ,,59,250
Half Canal Francaouia 17 „ . — —

All buildings, machinery, live stock and other assets, being essential to the property, are included in the above valuation. The areas of the different classes are taken from Mr. Sursock's figures. The Half Canal Francaouia is a very Valuable asset, hot not being lettable I have put no value against it. The land tax payable to Government varies from P.T. 5 to P.T. 57 per feddan, and, according to Mr. Sursock's figures, amounts at present to L.E. 653.646 mill, which is not heavy, as land tax runs, being only an average of P.T. 13 3/5 per feddan, but this, of course, will be increased as the land is reclaimed.

div.head: BOURSE DU CAIRE
div.p: Les architectes qui se préparaient au con cours des projets pour un Palais de la Bourse da Caire, ont été quetqae peu froissés da fait de la prolongation arbitraire de la date de le consigne des travaux, prolongation accordés pour permettre l'arrivée de projets de l'étranger. Le jury, appelé à décider sur les projects exposés, ne doit pas oublier cette circonstance et, à mérite égal, se prononcer en faveur de cenx qui étaient prêts an jour et à l'heure fixés.

Il y a pea à choisir entre les treize projets exposés, oar la plupart de leurs auteurs ont oublié de donner à l'édifice le caraotère monumental et spéoial à ces sortes de construotions. Vous y voyez, par example, si l'on en juge par l'aspeot extérieur, des théâtres, des villas, des maisons de rapport, des magasins même, ce qui est bien loin do bat da conoonrs, destiné à donner naissance, d'après le programme, à une œuvre d'art
Ceux qui répondent le mieux an but pour-suivi sont, a mon avis, les Nos. 1, 4 et 13, trois travaux de premier ordre et qui révèlent chez leurs antenrs une compétence indiscutable.

Le No. 1 Art et Labeur, qui présente aussi une maquette en plastiline, se recommande par une valeur artiitiqae exceptionnelle, une décoration intérieure très riche et un ensemble très agréable. Le No. 4 Vox Populi, conçu sur le même plan est an travail sans doute remarquable, mais la façade d'entrée est d'une pauvreté qui jare avec tout le reste de l'é lifice. Le No. 18 Nuccia est d'une richesse décorative admirable. Je ne discute pas ici la distribution intérieure ; je me borne à faire observer que la salle de la Corbeille do No. 4 se trouve par sa disposition même obligés à servir de passage.
JUSTUS

Le taux de l'escompte libre k Londres vient d'être augmanté de.1/8 k 5 5/8 pour cent. Hier, aa Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé de 1/8 k 86 5/8. L'Unifiée est restée invariés k 102. La National Bank a gagné 1/8 k 28 S.S. L'Agrioole est demeurée inchangée à 9 7/8, de même que la Daïra k 17 3/4 et la Delta Light k 12 3/4.

A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a avancé de 1 tranc k 787. La Banque d'Athènes a haussé de non moins de 10 fraucs k 143 Les Lots turse oat pardu 5 francs k 115 L'Enpraut russe a passé de 86.30 k 86 70.

loi, la séance da ce matin a été bonne dans son ensemble. Si le calme a régné sur une partie de la cote, il y ea, en revanche, beau coup d'animation sur diverses valeurs. notamment sur les National Bank, les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux, les Nungovich et les Egyptien Hotels, les parts de fondateur Héliopolis, ainsi que les M»rkets.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a avanoé de 28 1/2 9/16. L'Agrioole s'est tassée k 9 13/16. La Banque d'Athèaes est remontée k 138 ; suivant un té'égramme d'Athènes, cet établissement participe pour un quart dans le nouvel emprunt da gouvernement helléaiqae. La Banqae d'Abyssinie s'est relevée k 5 8/4-7/8.
La Daïra s'est Mffsrmie à 17 1/2. La N !e Land a gagné 3/8 à 19 1 /2. L'E iterpriee and Development s'est alourdie k 13 15/16 et sa part k 22 1/2.
Ei très bonne teudauos, les Entreprises I n mobilières et Travaux oat débuté k4 15/(6 poar atteindre 5 1/4-5/16. Oo s'attend encore k mieux, k bref délai, d'autant plus qu'il existerait an déoonvert.
Les Improvements oat été poussés k 6 1/2 l'aotiou anoieane et 5 15/16 6 la nouvelle. Oi oramt que ces prix ne puitseut pas être maintenus, étant donné le flottant considérable
Les Improvements out été recherches, a 6 1/2 leur part de fondateur a ete l'objet d'un fort mouvement qui les a fait monter a 12 1/2 5/3
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, Nungovich ont avancé a 22 1/8 3/16 et les Egyptien k 9 5/8. Les Excelsior ont été ramenés 1 4 3/8. Les National ont progressé &
1 1/8-3/16 et leur part k 77. 78.
Parmi les petites vrieurs, les Delta Land pnt été calmes à 4 7/8. Les Estâtes ont été
négociés a 2 9/16 et leur part a 20 1/8. Les
Abdy ont débuté k 1 1,2-9/16 pour clôturer à
1 7/16 1/2. Les Marke's out atteint jusqua
32/3 pour finir a 31/3. Las Khédivial Mail ont fléehi a 41/3, tes Hookar a 1/4 et les Salt and Soda a 25/6.

Toures sortes de rumeurs sont mises en circulation depuis quelques jours relativement k la Delta Land and Investment Co La plupart de cas informations sont favorables, ce qai explique la bonne tenue da titre. Elles se rapportent généralement k une pins value considérable qae 1er terrains de la Société k Meadi pourraient a quérir par suite de cer-aines combinaisons financières.

D'après un aatie brait, qai teud k prendre de la consistanos, des dissentiment' se seraient élevés entre le Board de Londres et les administrateurs locaux k propos da la ligne de conduite k suivre dans le projet de vente d'une partie des proprié és de la Compagnie. Il serait question de renforcer le comité administratif local, de manière k lai donner la prédominance sar le Board de Londres.

Il va de soi qu'il est encore difficile de se prononcer sur la valeur réelle de ces allégations. Toujours est-il qu'ilest fortement question de la convocation prochaine d'une assemblée extraordinaire des actionnaires appelée k statuer sur ce litige on prétendu litige.
Une erreur de plume nous a fait dire hier, dans notre compte rendu de l'assemb'ée des Excelrior Hotels, que le courtage voté pour la vente du terrain serait de 1 1/4 pour cent

Ce "lapsas calami" nous a vain le plaisir de recevoir an mot gracieux de S. E. Chikonr pacha, président da conseil d'administration de la Société. Son Excellence a fait, en outre, l'annotation suivante an bas de notre extrait da compte-renda détaillé pabliéen supplément:
"Jesuis complètcmeat d'accord sur cette rédtotfon, sous réserve de la question du coartage, qui est de £ 1 1/4 par mètre, soit 2 1/2 o/o, sar le prix de 50 livres.—Signé
J. Chakoar."
Dans le met précité adressé k notre sienr H. de Vries, S. E. Chakoar pacha ajoute :
"Le courtage voté est de £11/4 par mètre et non de 1 1/4 %. 8ar le prix de 50 livres,
1 £ 1/4 représente 2 1/2 % Votre tont dévoué J. Chakoar.
Ou voit par oe qui précède qae tout le monde était parfaitement d'accord. Et dire qu'oa a failli plaider !
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: Sale of lvory Rubber,

It is noticed for general information that the Assistant Secretary, Stored Section will sell by Public Auction at the Beit El Amana, Omdurman, on Monday 16tb Deœmber 1906 at 10 a.m. punctually, the following approximate quantities of ivory, rubber, etc.
Rottles
3085 Aal No. 1.
3693 Aal No. 2.
4201 Mashmouse
1647 Bar more than 10 rottles
738 Bar less than 10 tottles
766 Kling
417 Khorda
742 Rubber
3 Rhine horn
43 Giraffe skins.
The ivory will be sold in suitable lots at the rate of so much per kantar.

Immature ivory acquired under section 17 of the ordinance for the préservation of wild animais and birds 1903 is sold under condition that same is not resold in the Sudan and most be exported ex Sadan within one month from date of purchase and a permit for same will be issued at the time of purchase.

Ten per cent of the value must be paid by the purchaser at the conclusion of the auction and the balance within 5 days from the above date, after which period it will remain at per chaser's risk and be subjeot to a demurrage charge of 100 millièmes per each kantar per diem until whole stock is removed.
None of the articles sold can be removed before the whole of the purchase money has been paid.
The payment will be in cash and no cheques will be accepted.
The Government dues not bind itself to accept the highest or any offer.
(Signed) M. Courre, Kaim.
Assistant Secretary,
Stores Section.
Khartonm, 29th November, 1906. 29014-6-1

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: FRESKEL.
div.p: WHAT IT IS
FRESKEL is a dry powdered preparation for Wall and Ceiling Decoration, made ready for use with the addition of water.
It is easily prepared and applied.
WHAT IT DOES
FRESKEL, covers well, and works easy Does not crack, peel, or show brush marks. Does not rub off.
ECONOMICAL - EFFECTIVE.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905

Dr. Le Clerc's
Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
Dr. Le Clerc's Soap.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.
